title: Causality

articles.content: The law of causality is the law of identity applied to action. All actions are caused by entities. The nature of an action is caused and determined by the nature of the entities that act; a thing cannot act in contradiction to its nature . . . . The law of identity does not permit you to have your cake and eat it, too. The law of causality does not permit you to eat your cake before you have it.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 151

articles.content:
To grasp the axiom that existence exists, means to grasp the fact that nature,
i.e., the universe as a whole, cannot be created or annihilated, that it cannot
come into or go out of existence.  Whether its basic constituent elements are
atoms, or subatomic particles, or some yet undiscovered forms of energy, it is
not ruled by a consciousness or by will or by chance, but by the law of
identity.  All the countless forms, motions, combinations and dissolutions of
elements within the universe—from a floating speck of dust to the formation of
a galaxy to the emergence of life—are caused and determined by the identities
of the elements involved.
articles.attribution:
“The Metaphysical and the Man-Made,”
Philosophy: Who Needs It, 25

articles.content:
Since things are what they are, since everything that exists possesses a
specific identity, nothing in reality can occur causelessly or by chance.
articles.attribution:
Leonard Peikoff “The Analytic-Synthetic Dichotomy,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 108

articles.content:
Choice . . . is not chance. Volition is not an exception to the Law of
Causality; it is a type of causation.
articles.attribution:
Leonard Peikoff “The Analytic-Synthetic Dichotomy,”
Introduction to Objectivist Epistemology, 110

acknowledgement:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 151
